Abstract

Federated learning (FL) enables wireless terminals to collaboratively learn a shared parameter model while keeping all the training data on devices per se. Parameter sharing consists of synchronous and asynchronous ways: the former transmits parameters as blocks or frames and waits until all transmissions finish, whereas the latter provides messages about the status of pending and failed parameter transmission requests. Whatever synchronous or asynchronous parameter sharing is applied, the learning model shall adapt to distinct network architectures as an improper learning model will deteriorate learning performance and, even worse, lead to model divergence for the asynchronous transmission in resource-limited large-scale Internet-of-Things (IoT) networks. This paper proposes a decentralized learning model and develops an asynchronous parameter-sharing algorithm for resource-limited distributed IoT networks. This decentralized learning model approaches a convex function as the number of nodes increases, and its learning process converges to a global stationary point with a higher probability than the centralized FL model. Moreover, by jointly accounting for the convergence bound of federated learning and the transmission delay of wireless communications, we develop a node scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm to minimize the transmission delay. Extensive simulation results corroborate the effectiveness of the distributed algorithm in terms of fast learning model convergence and low transmission delay.

Index Terms:
Asynchronous communications, distributed algorithm, federated learning, large-scale IoT networks, transmission delay.

I Introduction

The phenomenal development of wireless networking technologies yields a volume of various sensory data, such as traffic information and industrial Internet of Things (IIoT) data. As massive amounts of data are typically required to train a machine learning (ML) model, e.g., convolutional neural networks (CNN), traditional ML algorithms must gather training data from edge devices. Moreover, to realize data sharing, it is essential to transmit a large dataset to an edge server for training ML models. However, limited communication resources for data transmission and conveying large volumes of data by edge devices may substantially burden wireless communications, regardless of privacy constraints. Therefore, edge learning has been proposed to train local models over distributed edge nodes, allowing edge nodes to contribute to the learning procedure for consensus without any raw data exchange. More specifically, federated learning (FL) is, in essence, collaborative edge learning, which deploys large data over multiple edge nodes and then collaborates in training local models without sharing their possibly private data. Moreover, various network architectures regarding computational models and communication mechanisms exist to realize efficient computation and reliable communications.

I-A Related Works and Motivation

From the perceptive of computational models, there are two main categories: centralized and decentralized, as shown in Fig.Â 1. Specifically, the federated averaging model is a typical centralized model with a central server to orchestrate a training process, as shown in Fig.Â 1a. After receiving local models from the participating nodes, the central server is responsible for parameter aggregation [1]. However, the centralized model requires massive communications between the edge server and nodes, which is usually not feasible. To deal with this infeasibility, decentralized FL models have recently emerged to significantly reduce the transmission delay because all nodes only communicate with their neighbors, as shown in Fig.Â 1b. For example, the work [2] optimizes the linking weights of peer-to-peer communications to realize efficient communication in the decentralized scheme. The work [3] exploits the cross gradients and develops a novel decentralized learning algorithm, which reduces the communication cost and maintains a satisfactory learning performance for various data distributions.

From the perceptive of communication mechanisms, there are synchronous transmission [4, 5] and asynchronous transmission [6, 7]. For a synchronous scheme, the server cannot aggregate local models until participating nodes finish uploading their local models. Specifically, the works [4, 5] adopt synchronous FL architectures to balance resource budget and learning accuracy adaptively. By using dynamic aggregation frequency [4] or node scheduling [5], these architectures could address resource-limited problems in the learning process. Nevertheless, while multiple nodes have extensive data for model training or suffer from high transmission delays, synchronous schemes must wait for uploading models. Moreover, the waiting time leads to idling and wastage of computational resources. To address these issues, asynchronous schemes are proposed. The works [6, 7] design asynchronous FL systems to reduce transmission delay. However, these asynchronous schemes may yield objective inconsistency, i.e., the learning model may be far from the desired one. The inconsistency between local and global models potentially deteriorates convergence and, even worse, leads to model divergence as the number of iterations increases. In addition, asynchronous schemes often lack theoretical identifications to guarantee convergence, particularly for non-convex FL models.

From the perspective of wireless resource allocation, many works have been on designing communication-efficient FL algorithms that enable edge nodes to efficiently train and transmit model parameters and significantly improve learning performance and convergence rate. For instance, the works [8, 9] focus on joint scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm designs while guaranteeing learning performance. To characterize the theoretical relations between the number of communication rounds and learning performance, the work [10] made a tradeoff for joint optimization, including communication latencies and energy consumption. Hence, realizing efficient communication and minimizing transmission delay is essential for distributed algorithms in large-scale IoT networks.

This paper develops a decentralized FL model with asynchronous parameter sharing to address the abovementioned issues. In particular, the proposed model has multi-branch architectures and allows various learning parameters at each node, forming a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions. By recalling the Shapley-Folkman lemma [11], a sum of multi-branch non-convex functions can approach a convex function when the number of branches becomes large. Thus, the decentralized FL model is less non-convex, and its learning process converges to a global stationary point with a higher probability than the centralized FL model. In addition, when the dataset is uniformly deployed over each node, and the size of the dataset becomes large, the learning performance and convergence rate of training algorithms improve with the number of distributed nodes increases.111In principle, the assumption requires that the data distribution at each node is identical to the distribution of the total dataset [12], which is unfortunately hard to satisfy in real-world applications. To address this issue, the cross-gradient aggregation (CGA) algorithm is widely used in simulation experiments to approach the distribution of the total dataset [3]. On the one hand, the asynchronous parameter-sharing mechanism makes the learning and parameter transmission occur in parallel. Thus, a high learning efficiency can be obtained compared with a synchronous architecture. On the other hand, designing a decentralized FL model at the distributed nodes requires an efficient communication network that balances learning performance maximization and transmission delay minimization. In this regard, the asynchronous parameter-sharing method is adopted among distributed nodes. Accordingly, we derive a convergence bound incorporating transmission delay and learning performance. In light of the convergence bound and aggregated duration, we also develop algorithms regarding node scheduling and bandwidth allocation to minimize the transmission delay while maximizing the learning performance. In brevity, TableÂ I compares the state-of-the-art and proposed schemes.

I-B Summary of Main Results

This paper starts to develop a decentralized FL model with non-convex loss functions. Then, we characterize the duality gap of the decentralized FL model by using the seminal Shapley-Folkman lemma. Next, we design a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and derive its convergence bound, where the transmission delay is associated with the convergence bound. At last, we design a node scheduling and bandwidth allocation algorithm to minimize the transmission delay. In brief, the major contributions of the paper are summarized as follows:

  • 1)

    A normalized duality gap is analytically attained to measure the degree of non-convexity for the decentralized FL model. This duality gap is essential to obtain a convex relaxation on loss functions, reducing the influence of non-convexity and making convergence faster.

  • 2)

    A distributed algorithm is developed to learn our decentralized model, including a gradient descent algorithm and asynchronous parameter-sharing principles. Specifically, asynchronous parameter sharing mitigates the influence of stochastic transmission delays.

  • 3)

    The transmission delay is minimized to enhance the convergence rate via efficient node scheduling and bandwidth allocation. By the convergence bound and the transmission delay, minimizing the transmission delay improves learning performance.

I-C Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ II formulates the decentralized learning problem. SectionÂ III derives a normalized duality gap between the primal and dual problems. SectionÂ IV develops a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and derives its convergence bound. SectionÂ V establishes the relationship between the transmission delay and convergence bound and allocates radio resources to minimize the transmission delay effectively. SectionÂ VI presents and discusses the experimental results; finally, SectionÂ VII concludes the paper.

Moreover, (3b) denotes a soft constraint in which the corresponding hard constraint is replaced by regularization. This replacement can control the complexity of a neural network model to avoid over-fitting and restrict the divergence of parameters arising due to heterogeneity in the data distribution [19].

Remark 1.

The proposed decentralized model can attain a higher learning efficiency and less non-convex FL model than the centralized one since the former makes the learning and data exchange parallel. Also, the latter with cell-interior scheduling leads to data deficiency since the resultant model training fails to exploit data at cell-edge devices[20]. To address this issue, the proposed method uses the shared parameter with the desired transmission delay and then improves the data quantity.

So far, we have formulated a decentralized FL problem. By recalling the seminal Shapley-Folkman lemma, we can infer that the sum result in the objective function of ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 becomes more and more convex as the number of nodes (i.e., Iğ¼I) increases. Therefore, designing algorithms to solve ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 efficiently improves the FL convergence rate.

III Duality Gap of The Decentralized FL Model

Although we have formulated a multi-branch problem, building a direct relationship between the node distribution and loss function takes time and effort. To address this issue, this section derives a normalized duality gap between the decentralized FL problem and its dual one to measure the degree of non-convexity. To start with, the dual problem of ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 is given by

Theorem 1.

0â‰¤inf(ğ’«â€‹1)âˆ’sup(ğ’«â€‹2)Î”worstâ‰¤2â€‹Î±max,0infimumğ’«1supremumğ’«2subscriptÎ”worst2subscriptğ›¼0\leq\dfrac{\inf(\mathcal{P}1)-\sup(\mathcal{P}2)}{\Delta_{\rm worst}}\leq 2\alpha_{\max}, (7)

where Î±maxâ‰œmaxi=1,2,â‹¯,Iâ¡Î±iâ‰œsubscriptğ›¼subscriptğ‘–12â‹¯ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–\alpha_{\max}\triangleq\max_{i=1,2,\cdots,I}\alpha_{i}.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ A. âˆ

In TheoremÂ 1, although the divergence Î”isubscriptÎ”ğ‘–\Delta_{i} changes from node to node, the maximal divergence Î”worstsubscriptÎ”worst\Delta_{\rm worst} among all nodes remains almost the same in case the number Iğ¼I of nodes is large enough. Accordingly, the normalized duality gap (inf(ğ’«â€‹1)âˆ’sup(ğ’«â€‹2))/Î”worstinfimumğ’«1supremumğ’«2subscriptÎ”worst\left(\inf(\mathcal{P}1)-\sup(\mathcal{P}2)\right)/\Delta_{\rm worst} in (7) measures the degree of non-convexity for the objective function. When differences in the data distribution among all distributed nodes turn larger, i.e., Î±maxâ†’1â†’subscriptğ›¼1\alpha_{\max}\rightarrow 1, the upper bound of (7) becomes looser, and the proposed model degenerates into a centralized FL model. In contrast, when a large dataset has a uniform distribution over each node, i.e., Î±1=â‹¯=Î±I=Î±maxâ†’1/Isubscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ¼subscriptğ›¼â†’1ğ¼\alpha_{1}=\cdots=\alpha_{I}=\alpha_{\max}\rightarrow 1/I, the upper bound of (7) takes the minimum value, i.e., 2/I2ğ¼2/I. Clearly, the normalized duality gap decreases linearly withÂ Iğ¼I. In other words, ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 becomes more and more convex as Iğ¼I increases. As a result, the solution of ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 approaches that of ğ’«â€‹2ğ’«2\mathcal{P}2 as Iâ†’+âˆâ†’ğ¼I\rightarrow+\infty.

IV Algorithm Design and Convergence Analysis

By using the duality gap, we can now control the non-convexity of our decentralized FL model by adjusting the number of nodes. The learning process can also converge to a global solution with a high probability. Next, we develop a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing, followed by an analytical upper bound to guarantee convergence.

IV-A Algorithm Design

Based on the decentralized FL model shown in Fig.Â 2, we now design a distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing for learning relative parameters. The following assumptions are prerequisites for convergence.

Assumption 1 (pp. 483-484 of [21]).

Assume that the number of transmission delays Î“Î“\Gamma, i.e., how usually all scheduled nodes participate in an asynchronous aggregation, is a positive integer, then the transmission iteration Ï„i,jâ€‹(t)subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\tau_{i,\,j}(t) satisfies

However, ğ’˜i|shsubscriptğ’˜conditionalğ‘–sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} cannot be updated in parallel as it requires information from other nodes. Therefore, we replace the gradient descent algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing, yielding

Now, we apply gradient descent algorithms to learn our FL model. At first, ğ’˜iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{i}(t) can be updated by

For illustrative purposes, Fig.Â 3 shows the schematic diagram for iterative learning processes, where different colored disks denote different learning iterations. By unfolding the time-series data, Fig.Â 3 also illustrates the network topology with transmission delays. In particular, parameter reception and transmission are two main processes. In the period of the parameter reception, node iğ‘–i starts receiving the parameters from the other nodes at the tthsuperscriptğ‘¡tht^{\rm th} iteration. Specifically, node jğ‘—j transmits ğ’˜jâ€‹(Ï„i,jâ€‹(t))subscriptğ’˜ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right) to node iğ‘–i at the (Ï„i,jâ€‹(t))thsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡th\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right)^{\rm th} iteration, where we take Î“i,jâ‰œtâˆ’Ï„i,jâ€‹(t)â‰œsubscriptÎ“ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\Gamma_{i,\,j}\triangleq t-\tau_{i,\,j}(t) as a communication duration and the parameter ğ’˜jâ€‹(Ï„i,jâ€‹(t))subscriptğ’˜ğ‘—subscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{j}\left(\tau_{i,\,j}(t)\right) rather than the up-to-date ğ’˜jâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’˜ğ‘—ğ‘¡\bm{w}_{j}(t) is used at the tthsuperscriptğ‘¡tht^{\rm th} iteration. After receiving all parameters of the set â„âˆ–iâ„ğ‘–\mathcal{I}\setminus i, node iğ‘–i performs the iteration (13). On the other hand, in the period of the parameter transmission, node iğ‘–i transmits the corresponding parameter ğ’˜iâ€‹(t+1)subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\bm{w}_{i}(t+1) to nodes in the set â„âˆ–iâ„ğ‘–\mathcal{I}\setminus i, where we take Î“j,isubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{j,\,i} as a communication duration between node iğ‘–i and node jğ‘—j.

IV-B Convergence Analysis

Now, we characterize the convergence for the distributed algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing. Compared with traditional convergence analysis, it is hard to prove the convergence of our proposed algorithm due to shared and local learning parameters. To address this issue, this paper designs a new loss function that mitigates the influence of shared parameters and establishes the convergence relationship. First, we define this loss function as

FÂ¯â€‹(ğ’˜)â‰œâˆ‘i=1IÎ±iâ€‹Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)=âˆ‘i=1IÎ±iâ€‹Fiâ€‹(âˆ‘i=1IÎ±iâ€‹ğ’˜i),â‰œÂ¯ğ¹ğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}\right)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}F_{i}\left(\bm{w}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}\right), (14)

where ğ’˜â€‹(t)â‰œâˆ‘i=1IÎ±iâ€‹ğ’˜iâ€‹(t)â‰œğ’˜ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–subscriptğ’˜ğ‘–ğ‘¡\bm{w}(t)\triangleq\sum_{i=1}^{I}\alpha_{i}\bm{w}_{i}(t) stands for the last aggregated parameter, unlike ğ’—iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘¡\bm{v}_{i}(t) shown in (9). Since the objective function in (3a) is indeterminate due to the stochastic transmission delays, (14) rather than (3a) is applied in the following convergence analysis. Then, it is sufficient to require that each variable is updated in a gradient descent direction. Accordingly, the following assumptions are introduced for the convergence analysis.

Assumption 2 (pp. 527-528 of [21]).

The objective loss and descent gradient satisfy the following conditions:

  • (a)

    There holds Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜)â‰¥0,âˆ€iâˆˆâ„formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜0for-allğ‘–â„F_{i}(\bm{w})\geq 0,\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}.

  • (b)

    Any function âˆ‡Fiâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–\nabla F_{i} is continuously differentiable and there exists a constant L1subscriptğ¿1L_{1} such that

    â€–âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’š)â€–2â‰¤L1â€‹â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2,subscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’š2subscriptğ¿1subscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2\|\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})\|_{2}\leq L_{1}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|_{2},

    where âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™\nabla F_{i}(\bm{x}) (resp., âˆ‡Fi(ğ’š\nabla F_{i}(\bm{y})) represents the derivative with respect to the aggregated variable ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} (resp., ğ’šğ’š\bm{y}).

  • (c)

    For all iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, we have

    ğ’”iTâ€‹(t)â€‹âˆ‡iFiâ€‹(ğ’—iâ€‹(t))â‰¤0.superscriptsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğ‘¡subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘¡0\bm{s}_{i}^{T}(t)\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\leq 0.

    There are positive constants L2subscriptğ¿2L_{2} and L3subscriptğ¿3L_{3}, such that

    L2â€‹â€–âˆ‡iFiâ€‹(ğ’—iâ€‹(t))â€–2â‰¤â€–ğ’”iâ€‹(t)â€–2â‰¤L3â€‹â€–âˆ‡iFiâ€‹(ğ’—iâ€‹(t))â€–2.subscriptğ¿2subscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘¡2subscriptnormsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡2subscriptğ¿3subscriptnormsubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘¡2L_{2}\left\|\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right\|_{2}\leq\left\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)\right\|_{2}\leq L_{3}\left\|\nabla_{i}F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t))\right\|_{2}.
  • (e)

    There is a positive constant Î´ğ›¿\delta, such that

    â€–ğ’”iâ€‹(t)âˆ’ğ’”jâ€‹(t)â€–2â‰¤Î´â€‹minâ¡(â€–ğ’”iâ€‹(t)â€–2,â€–ğ’”jâ€‹(t)â€–2),subscriptnormsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ’”ğ‘—ğ‘¡2ğ›¿subscriptnormsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡2subscriptnormsubscriptğ’”ğ‘—ğ‘¡2\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)-\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}\leq\delta\min\left(\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)\|_{2},\,\|\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}\right),

    where Î´ğ›¿\delta is a convergence bound of â€–ğ’”iâ€‹(t)âˆ’ğ’”jâ€‹(t)â€–2subscriptnormsubscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡subscriptğ’”ğ‘—ğ‘¡2\|\bm{s}_{i}(t)-\bm{s}_{j}(t)\|_{2}.

AssumptionÂ 2(a) means that the loss functions take non-negative values. The smooth assumption given by AssumptionÂ 2(b) indicates how fast the gradient of Fiâ€‹(ğ’™)subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’™F_{i}(\bm{x}) can change. AssumptionÂ 2(c) implies that ğ’”iâ€‹(t)subscriptğ’”ğ‘–ğ‘¡\bm{s}_{i}(t) must be in the same Cartesian quadrant as âˆ’âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’—iâ€‹(t))âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘¡-\nabla F_{i}(\bm{v}_{i}(t)). To avoid gradient exploding and ensure the convergence of model training, AssumptionÂ 2(d) is necessary to restrict the scale of gradients. Moreover, AssumptionÂ 2(e) means a bounded local dissimilarity and a divergence of the gradients. It is evident that AssumptionsÂ 2(d) and 2(e) reveal the data heterogeneity and distribution over edge nodes [4]. All the assumptions mentioned above characterize the key features of loss and risk functions of existing machine learning models, which have been widely used in the literature about the convergence analysis of machine learning models, even for non-convex models [19, 23, 24].

By virtue of AssumptionÂ 2, we obtain the following lemma on FÂ¯â€‹(ğ’˜)Â¯ğ¹ğ’˜\bar{F}(\bm{w}):

Lemma 2.

For any ğ°ğ°\bm{w} and ğ°isubscriptğ°ğ‘–\bm{w}_{i}, we have

âˆ‡FÂ¯â€‹(ğ’˜)=âˆ‘i=1Iâˆ‡iFiâ€‹(âˆ‘j=1IÎ±jâ€‹ğ’˜j),âˆ‡Â¯ğ¹ğ’˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ¼subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—subscriptğ’˜ğ‘—\nabla\bar{F}\left(\bm{w}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{I}\nabla_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{I}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\right), (15)

and

â€–âˆ‡FÂ¯â€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡FÂ¯â€‹(ğ’š)â€–2â‰¤L1â€‹â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’šâ€–2,âˆ€ğ’™,ğ’šâˆˆğ’².formulae-sequencesubscriptnormâˆ‡Â¯ğ¹ğ’™âˆ‡Â¯ğ¹ğ’š2subscriptğ¿1subscriptnormğ’™ğ’š2for-allğ’™ğ’šğ’²\|\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{x})-\nabla\bar{F}(\bm{y})\|_{2}\leq L_{1}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|_{2},\,\forall\bm{x},\,\bm{y}\in\mathcal{W}. (16)
Proof.

By definition, we have

âˆ‡iFiâ€‹(âˆ‘j=1IÎ±jâ€‹ğ’˜j)=Î±iâ€‹âˆ‡Fiâ€‹(ğ’˜).subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘–subscriptğ¹ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ¼subscriptğ›¼ğ‘—subscriptğ’˜ğ‘—subscriptğ›¼ğ‘–âˆ‡subscriptğ¹ğ‘–ğ’˜\nabla_{i}F_{i}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{I}\alpha_{j}\bm{w}_{j}\right)=\alpha_{i}\nabla F_{i}(\bm{w}). (17)

Summing up (17) for iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I} and inserting it into (14) yields (15). On the other hand, by AssumptionÂ 2(b), we get

In essence, (20) implies that each model can converge independently; (21) shows that we can obtain an aggregated model at each node, which converges to the same global model. The reason behind these observations is that the sharing parameter ğ’˜i|shsubscriptğ’˜conditionalğ‘–sh\bm{w}_{i|{\rm sh}} can restrict the severity of local deviations if they increase with the number of iterations.

CorollaryÂ 2 states that the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta is naturally in a reasonable range to guarantee convergence. The convergence rate is prolonged if Î·ğœ‚\eta is small. On the other hand, if Î·ğœ‚\eta is large, the term involving Î·2superscriptğœ‚2\eta^{2} in the parenthesis of (19) cannot be ignored anymore, yielding stochastic fluctuations due to different transmission delays among nodes. In the next section, we aim to minimize the maximum of transmission delays.

V Wireless Resource Allocation

In this section, we develop efficient communications for parameter sharing in highly distributed networks. In particular, it is observed from TheoremÂ 2 that minimizing the upper bound is essential to obtain a good convergence in each iteration period. Therefore, it is natural to minimize the convergence bound Uâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘ˆÎ“U(\Gamma) defined in (19) concerning the aggregated duration Î“Î“\Gamma, where Î“â‰œÎ“W+Î“Tâ‰œÎ“subscriptÎ“ğ‘ŠsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma\triangleq\Gamma_{W}+\Gamma_{T} includes the number of waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} and the maximal transmission duration Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T}. Specifically, Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} is from the reserved duration for unscheduled nodes [25], and Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T} is associated with the transmission delay [26]. However, as Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} varies due to the randomness of channels, it is hard to express Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} explicitly and provide a corresponding optimization. Therefore, we design a scheduling strategy and a bandwidth allocation algorithm for efficient wireless resource allocation.

Like [5, 27], we consider a typical wireless network where all user nodes are uniformly distributed. The network coverage area is tessellated into Voronoi cells using the nearest-neighbor association criteria, i.e., each node is associated with its nearest base station (BS) [28]. We assume that the locations of user nodes follow a homogeneous Poisson point process (PPP) with a pre-defined spatial density. A fixed amount of spectrum resource is divided into multiple spectrum bands for efficient spectral utilization. Each node with a single antenna broadcasts the same parameters to others through its allocated spectrum band. A block-fading propagation model is adopted, where the channels between any two nodes are independently and identically distributed (i.i.d.) and keep quasi-static in the parameter transmission period. In addition, the propagation channels are supposed to be narrow-band (which is true in IoT applications), and large-scale path loss and small-scale fading are accounted for as usual.

V-A Scheduling Strategy

In this subsection, we start to analyze the waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} during transmission. Using Slivnyakâ€™s theorem, it is sufficient to evaluate the communication quality through the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) at a typical node [6]. For the parameter transmission from node iğ‘–i to jğ‘—j, the SINR at node jğ‘—j can be expressed as [29]

SINRj,i=Pâ€‹hj,iâ€‹dj,iâˆ’Î±âˆ‘xâˆˆÎ¦jPâ€‹hj,xâ€‹dj,xâˆ’Î±+Ïƒ2,subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ›¼subscriptğ‘¥subscriptÎ¦ğ‘—ğ‘ƒsubscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘¥superscriptsubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğ›¼superscriptğœ2{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}=\dfrac{Ph_{j,\,i}d_{j,\,i}^{-\alpha}}{\sum_{x\in\Phi_{j}}Ph_{j,\,x}d_{j,\,x}^{-\alpha}+\sigma^{2}}, (24)

where all nodes are assumed to have the same transmit power Pğ‘ƒP, the symbol hj,iâˆ¼expâ¡(1)similar-tosubscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–1h_{j,\,i}\sim\exp(1) reflects a small-scale fading with unity power (i.e., ğ”¼â€‹{|hj,i|2}=1ğ”¼superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘—ğ‘–21\mathbb{E}\{|h_{j,\,i}|^{2}\}=1), dj,isubscriptğ‘‘ğ‘—ğ‘–d_{j,\,i} denotes a Euclidean distance between nodes iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a path loss exponent, the set Î¦jsubscriptÎ¦ğ‘—\Phi_{j} stands for out-of-cell nodes interfering with node jğ‘—j, and Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} denotes the variance of additive white Gaussian noises.

Due to the limited wireless resources of low-cost IoT nodes, they are divided into distinct groups, each associated with a particular learning task. Accordingly, each node exchanges its learning parameters within the group per se. To obtain good communication qualities in the transmission period, the SINR must exceed a threshold Î³ğ›¾\gamma, i.e., SINRj,i>Î³subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–ğ›¾{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma at node jğ‘—j [30]; otherwise, a transmission outage occurs. Meanwhile, we define two different node sets as

ğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\displaystyle\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1) â‰œ{j|ğ•€â€‹(SINRj,i>Î³)=1,âˆ€jâˆˆâ„âˆ–i},â‰œabsentconditional-setğ‘—formulae-sequenceğ•€subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–ğ›¾1for-allğ‘—â„ğ‘–\displaystyle\triangleq\left\{j\left|\mathbb{I}\left({\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma\right)=1,\,\forall j\in\mathcal{I}\setminus i\right.\right\}, (25a)
â„Â¯Â¯â„\displaystyle\bar{\mathcal{I}} â‰œ{iâˆˆâ„|ğ•€â€‹(ğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)â‰ âˆ…)=1},âˆ€iâˆˆâ„,formulae-sequenceâ‰œabsentconditional-setğ‘–â„ğ•€subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡11for-allğ‘–â„\displaystyle\triangleq\{i\in\mathcal{I}|\mathbb{I}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset\right)=1\},\,\forall i\in\mathcal{I}, (25b)

where ğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1) represents the set of nodes that receive parameters from node iğ‘–i, and â„Â¯Â¯â„\bar{\mathcal{I}} is the set of nodes that have been scheduled in this wireless network. More specifically, ğ•€â€‹(SINRj,i>Î³)ğ•€subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–ğ›¾\mathbb{I}\left({\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}>\gamma\right) denotes a scheduled state whether node iğ‘–i is scheduled by node jğ‘—j while ğ•€â€‹(ğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)â‰ âˆ…)ğ•€subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\mathbb{I}\left(\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset\right) represents a scheduled state whether node iğ‘–i has been scheduled at least once in this wireless network.

In theory, it is challenging to formulate an optimization problem about the SINR threshold Î³ğ›¾\gamma due to the varying Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W}. In practice, as the value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma depends on the expectation of wireless channels and SINR, it can be optimized numerically by a grid search [20]. To reduce the computational complexity, we consider two extreme cases for an appropriate Î³ğ›¾\gamma. If the wireless network operates at a relatively high SINR, i.e., Î³â‰«0much-greater-thanğ›¾0\gamma\gg 0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, the number of scheduled nodes decreases monotonically, as implied by (25). Hence, the number of waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} increases rapidly, yielding a large Î“Î“\Gamma. Clearly, a significant Î“Î“\Gamma would deteriorate the convergence process and require more training iterations. In contrast, if the wireless network operates at low SINR, i.e., Î³â‰ª0â€‹dBmuch-less-thanğ›¾0dB\gamma\ll 0\,{\rm dB}, the number of scheduled nodes increases rapidly. However, the additional nodes exacerbate the competition for communication resources, resulting in a considerable transmission duration Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T}, which also deteriorates the learning process. Consequently, we can conclude that an appropriate value Î³ğ›¾\gamma benefits making a balance between the waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} and the maximal transmission duration Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T} to minimize the total aggregated duration Î“Î“\Gamma. Moreover, it is widely known that SINR and Î³ğ›¾\gamma values depend heavily on the interference and channel fading among user nodes [31]. As the waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} reserved for unscheduled nodes is fixed if the scheduling is determined by (25), the maximal transmission duration Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T} can be employed to replace the optimal variable Î“Î“\Gamma for efficient resource allocation.

V-B Bandwidth Allocation

As illustrated in Fig.Â 3, Î“j,isubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{j,\,i} denotes the transmission duration in each parameter transmission period. Then, Î“TsubscriptÎ“ğ‘‡\Gamma_{T} can be computed as

Î“T=maxiâˆˆâ„Â¯â¡maxjâˆˆğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)â¡Î“j,i.subscriptÎ“ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘–Â¯â„subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{T}=\max_{i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}\max_{j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)}\Gamma_{j,\,i}. (26)

When the amount of transmission parameters is large, the parameter sparsity is necessarily accounted for to reduce transmission burden on wireless networks333It is well-known that when training a complex deep neural network model using stochastic gradient descent methods, model updates can be highly sparse. Indeed, it has been shown that when training some of the popular large-scale architectures, such as ResNet [32] or VGG [33], sparse levels of [0.001,0.01]0.0010.01\left[0.001,0.01\right] provides a significant reduction in the communication load with almost no loss in their generalization performance [34].. In practice, each node only transmits non-zero parameters and their locations [31], such that Î“j,isubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{j,\,i} can be computed as

Î“j,i=qiâ€‹STâ€‹Biâ€‹log2â¡(1+SINRj,i),âˆ€jâˆˆğ’´iâ€‹(t+1),iâˆˆâ„Â¯,formulae-sequencesubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘†ğ‘‡subscriptğµğ‘–subscript21subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–formulae-sequencefor-allğ‘—subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1ğ‘–Â¯â„\Gamma_{j,\,i}=\dfrac{q_{i}S}{TB_{i}\log_{2}\left(1+{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}\right)},\,\forall j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1),\,i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}, (27)

where qisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–q_{i} is a sparsity ratio, Sğ‘†S is the total amount of the quantized parameter bits, Tğ‘‡T is an average training latency for each iteration, and Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i} is an optimal bandwidth for nodeÂ iğ‘–i. In this paper, we set qi=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1q_{i}=1 since a weight decay 1/2â€‹â€–ğ’˜iâ€–2212superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘–221/2\|\bm{w}_{i}\|_{2}^{2} is considered for regularization terms.

To determine the transmission duration Î“j,isubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{j,\,i} shown in (27), we first assume that each node has a deterministic training latency Tğ‘‡T at each node444In this paper, we assume that each node has the similar computation capability, and all data samples at each node have the same data size. Therefore, we set the average training latency Tğ‘‡T as a constant for all nodes. A similar assumption is widely adopted in the literature, like [35]., and then estimate Tğ‘‡T in GPU modes. Unlike the serial mode of the CPU, the GPU processes datasets in parallel. When the training batch size is small, GPU can directly process the dataset simultaneously, yielding a constant training latencyÂ T0subscriptğ‘‡0T_{0}. On the contrary, the training latency Tğ‘‡T grows linearly if the training batch size exceeds a thresholdÂ Dthsubscriptğ·thD_{\rm th}. With this consideration, AssumptionÂ 111 in [24] describes a computation model on the local training latency Tğ‘‡T and the training batch size. It reveals that the local training latency grows linearly when the training batch size exceeds a threshold Dthsubscriptğ·thD_{\rm th}. Moreover, one training duration per iteration is usually as long as several seconds. It is because of the high computational complexity and the limited computation resource of nodes for processing large training sampling per iteration. However, communication time slots are relatively short [31]. Therefore, the transmission duration Î“j,isubscriptÎ“ğ‘—ğ‘–\Gamma_{j,\,i} computed by (27) is small. In light of (26) and (27), we formulate an achievable transmission rate maximization problem as

s.t.formulae-sequencest\displaystyle{\rm s.t.}\quad âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Â¯Biâ‰¤B,subscriptğ‘–Â¯â„subscriptğµğ‘–ğµ\displaystyle\sum_{i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}}B_{i}\leq B, (28b)

where BğµB is the total bandwidth. Clearly, ğ’«â€‹3ğ’«3\mathcal{P}{3} is indeed a transmission delay minimization problem, which is convex and can be easily solved by the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions [36, p. 243]. Therefore, the optimal bandwidth allocation can be formalized in the following proposition.

With PropositionÂ 1, our decentralized FL model can be readily deployed in wireless distributed networks. Accordingly, we formalize a distributed algorithm in AlgorithmÂ 1, where three types of states control the learning process. In particular, when the sharing parameter is transmitted from node jğ‘—j to iğ‘–i, the received state Ji,jsubscriptğ½ğ‘–ğ‘—J_{i,\,j} denotes whether node iğ‘–i has received the parameter from node jğ‘—j or not. The scheduled state Qi,jsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘—Q_{i,\,j} indicates whether node iğ‘–i schedules node jğ‘—j or not, while the state Yisubscriptğ‘Œğ‘–Y_{i} reflects whether other nodes schedule node iğ‘–i or not, i.e., ğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)â‰ âˆ…subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)\neq\emptyset, which is used to update the node set â„Â¯Â¯â„\bar{\mathcal{I}} defined by (25b).

Proposition 1 (Bandwidth allocation).

Given the node set â„Â¯Â¯â„\bar{\mathcal{I}} in the (t+1)thsuperscriptğ‘¡1th(t+1)^{\rm th} parameter transmission period, the optimal bandwidth allocation is given by

(29)

where Ri=minjâˆˆğ’´iâ€‹(t+1)â¡log2â¡(1+SINRj,i),iâˆˆâ„Â¯formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘…ğ‘–subscriptğ‘—subscriptğ’´ğ‘–ğ‘¡1subscript21subscriptSINRğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘–Â¯â„R_{i}=\min_{j\in\mathcal{Y}_{i}(t+1)}\log_{2}\left(1+{\rm SINR}_{j,\,i}\right),\,i\in\bar{\mathcal{I}}, is an average uplink data rate during the ithsuperscriptğ‘–thi^{\rm th} transmission period.

For better clarity of AlgorithmÂ 1, Fig.Â 4a shows the four built-in modules in each iteration period: a learning module, a parameter reception module, a bandwidth allocation module, and a parameter transmission module. In particular, Module 1, i.e., LineÂ 333 of AlgorithmÂ 1, states that the learning module includes local parameter aggregation and parameter updates. On the other hand, Figs.Â 4b-4d plots the flowcharts of ModulesÂ 2-4, respectively. In the parameter reception module, Fig.Â 4b shows that the current node receives the SINR, data rate, three states above, and learning parameters from other nodes, which are realized in linesÂ 4-9 of AlgorithmÂ 1. LinesÂ 101010-151515 realize the bandwidth allocation module shown in Fig.Â 4c. Among them, lineÂ 10 means that node iğ‘–i cannot transmit the current learning parameter to other nodes until it has finished all transmissions in the last parameter transmission process; lineÂ 11 sets a scheduling strategy for scheduled nodes. Each aggregated period has a separate iteration index tSsubscriptğ‘¡St_{\rm S} that records the moment of the parameter transmission. LineÂ 12 feeds main states back to other nodes, and linesÂ 13-14 compute the data rate and optimal bandwidth for the next iteration period. LinesÂ 16-21 realize the parameter transmission module shown in Fig.Â 4d, including two main steps: computing the SINR in lineÂ 17 and transmitting the learning parameters in linesÂ 18-20.

VI Simulation Results and Discussions

In this section, we present and discuss Monte-Carlo simulation results to exhibit the learning performance of the developed algorithm in terms of convergence analysis, node scheduling, and bandwidth allocation. In the pertaining simulation experiments, the workstation is equipped with an Intel(X) E555-262026202620 CPU and four NVIDIA GeForce RTX 309030903090 graphic cards. We build a TensorFlow (TF) simulation environment and then train our proposed model by the deterministic gradient descent algorithm.

VI-A Convergence Analysis

This subsection evaluates the learning performance of AlgorithmÂ 1 without bandwidth allocation. For comparison purposes, we perform experiments on two typical datasets using CNN as follows: the MNIST [37] and CIFAR datasets [38]. In particular, the MNIST dataset contains 70,0007000070,000 28Ã—28282828\times 28 grayscale images of handwritten digits (more specifically, 60,0006000060,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). The CIFAR dataset contains 60,0006000060,000 32Ã—32323232\times 32 color images (more specifically, 50,0005000050,000 for training and 10,0001000010,000 for testing). The images in each dataset are divided into 101010 classes with an equal number of images per class. The CNN has 999 layers with the following structure: 5Ã—5Ã—3255325\times 5\times 32 Convolutional â†’â†’\rightarrow 2Ã—2222\times 2 MaxPool â†’â†’\rightarrow Local Response Normalization â†’â†’\rightarrow 5Ã—5Ã—3255325\times 5\times 32 Convolutional â†’â†’\rightarrow Local Response Normalization â†’â†’\rightarrow 2Ã—2222\times 2 MaxPool â†’â†’\rightarrow zÃ—256ğ‘§256z\times 256 Fully connected â†’â†’\rightarrow 256Ã—1025610256\times 10 Fully connected â†’â†’\rightarrow Softmax, where z=1568ğ‘§1568z=1568 for the MNIST and z=2048ğ‘§2048z=2048 for the CIFAR [4]. In the simulation experiments, we consider five typical schemes: the centralized FL averaging model (FedAv for short) [1]; adaptive FL model (AdaFL for short) [4]; the FedAv-partial model (FedAP for short), in which the parameter server selects partial nodes for the global updating to avoid the impacts of stragglers [39]; the semi-asynchronous FL model (FedSA for short), where the parameter server aggregates a certain number of local models by their arrival order in each round [39]; and AlgorithmÂ 1 without bandwidth allocation, i.e., the pseudo-code in the box of AlgorithmÂ 1 is excluded (Alg.Â 111 w/o BWA for short). Note that AlgorithmÂ 1 is reduced for a fair comparison.

FigureÂ 5 depicts the learning performance versus the number of iterations, where the number of nodes is set to I=5,10,15ğ¼51015I=5,10,15. On the one hand, we observe from Fig.Â 5a that the training losses of AlgorithmÂ 1 are lower than those for comparison. The reason behind this observation is that our decentralized FL model of ğ’«â€‹1ğ’«1\mathcal{P}1 has a less-nonconvex objective function than the centralized FL averaging model [1] and adaptive FL model [4]. Also, it is observed that when the number of nodes increases from 555 to 101010 till 151515, the training loss of AlgorithmÂ 1 converges to a lower and lower value. This observation is because the normalized duality gap decreases as the number of nodes increases. Thus, our proposed model becomes more and more convex when a large dataset is distributed over each node uniformly. Consequently, this makes the learning process faster to obtain an optimal solution. On the other hand, Fig.Â 5b also shows that the testing accuracies of AlgorithmÂ 1 outperform the benchmark algorithms under study, and more nodes involved lead to higher testing accuracy, as expected. As far as the CIFAR dataset is concerned, Figs.Â 5c-5d show similar performance to Figs.Â 5a-5b, respectively. Accordingly, in the rest of this section, we only report the results regarding the MNIST dataset to reduce redundancy.

FigureÂ 6 illustrates the learning performance versus the number of iterations, where the transmission delays are set to Î“=5,10,15Î“51015\Gamma=5,10,15. In particular, the centralized FL averaging model is independent of Î“Î“\Gamma as the transmission delays and aggregated durations do not influence learning performance. On the one hand, Fig.Â 6a shows that the training losses of AlgorithmÂ 1 are lower than the benchmark algorithms under study. Moreover, as Î“Î“\Gamma decreases from 151515 to 101010 till 555, the training loss of AlgorithmÂ 1 becomes smaller and smaller. The reason behind these observations is that, given a smaller transmission delay Î“Î“\Gamma, our decentralized FL model can faster aggregate sharing parameters from other nodes, thus leading to a lower upper bound and a faster convergence rate, by TheoremÂ 2. Instead, when Î“Î“\Gamma becomes large, the proposed model can only obtain sharing parameters with a large delay, slightly slowing down the convergence. On the other hand, Fig.Â 6b shows that the testing accuracy of AlgorithmÂ 1 outperforms the benchmark algorithms under study, regardless of Î“Î“\Gamma.

VI-B Effect of Node Scheduling and Bandwidth Allocation

This subsection illustrates the effectiveness of node scheduling and bandwidth allocation. In the pertaining simulation experiments, we adopt similar wireless parameters as those reported in [27], and their default values are summarized in TableÂ III unless specified otherwise. Apart from the conventional centralized FL averaging model (FedAv for short) [1] and AlgorithmÂ 1 with optimal resource allocation (Alg.Â 111 for short), we also consider two other benchmark ones: the distributed FL algorithms with uniform bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Uniform for short) or random bandwidth allocation (Distributed+Random for short).

FigureÂ 7 illustrates the effect of node scheduling by adjusting different SINR thresholds (say, Î³ğ›¾\gamma) in AlgorithmÂ 1. On the one hand, Fig.Â 7a shows that, given Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, the training loss of AlgorithmÂ 1 is lower than those of Î³=âˆ’15ğ›¾15\gamma=-15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} and Î³=15ğ›¾15\gamma=15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}, and perform a bit smaller than the centralized algorithm. These observations are because, given a low SINR threshold Î³ğ›¾\gamma, many nodes are scheduled, and the channels with poor SINR cannot obtain sufficient bandwidth. As a result, the transmission delay and aggregated duration become large, thus leading to a low convergence rate. Meanwhile, many nodes are not scheduled given a high SINR threshold Î³ğ›¾\gamma. Hence, the waiting duration Î“WsubscriptÎ“ğ‘Š\Gamma_{W} reserved for unscheduled nodes increases, resulting in poor learning performance. On the other hand, Fig.Â 7b shows that the testing accuracy with Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} is higher than those of Î³=âˆ’15ğ›¾15\gamma=-15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B} and Î³=15ğ›¾15\gamma=15 dBdB\mathrm{d}\mathrm{B}. Therefore, adopting a medium SINR threshold is critical to achieving good convergence performance of our decentralized FL model.

FigureÂ 8 compares AlgorithmÂ 1 with state-of-the-art algorithms in resource-limited settings, including FedSA and FedAP, and AlgorithmÂ 1 with different bandwidth allocation mechanisms, including uniform and random allocation mechanisms. On the one hand, Fig.Â 8a shows that AlgorithmÂ 1 and the centralized algorithm achieve similar training losses, both lower than the benchmark ones under study. The reason stems from the fact that AlgorithmÂ 1 can allocate bandwidth optimally such that the transmission delay and aggregated duration can also be minimized. TheoremÂ 2 implies that a low aggregated duration leads to a low convergence bound and accelerates the training process. However, the random and uniform bandwidth allocations are not optimal, thus resulting in a longer transmission delay and aggregated duration than AlgorithmÂ 1. Moreover, it is observed that AlgorithmÂ 1 and FedSA have a lower learning loss than FedAP. The reason is that the FedAP algorithm only schedules partial nodes for the global aggregation and has data deficiency due to the communication stragglers. AlgorithmÂ 1 also has a lower learning loss than FedSA due to its sharing parameters and less non-convexity. On the other hand, Fig.Â 8b shows that the testing accuracy of AlgorithmÂ 1 is also higher than the others. Therefore, we can infer that the decentralized FL model with optimal bandwidth allocation enables efficient learning even in resource-limited wireless networks.

VII Concluding Remarks

This paper has developed a decentralized FL model with less non-convex summation functions to adapt to distributed network architecture, especially for resource-constrained large-scale IoT networks. With the increasing number of nodes, this paper has derived a duality gap to control the non-convexity of our proposed decentralized FL model and improve the learning performance. To realize efficient learning, this paper has also proposed a gradient descent algorithm with asynchronous parameter sharing and a convergence analysis to mitigate the influence of stochastic transmission delays. Moreover, we established the relationship between the convergence bound and the transmission delay for efficient communication and excellent learning performance in resource-constrained IoT networks. It improved the learning performance by minimizing the transmission delay. In future works, we will incorporate the data distribution divergence over nodes and design a new gradient descent to deal with insufficient data samples.
